page.normal_text:
Written Report – August 13, 2008
Written Report – August 13, 2008 W r i t t e n
R e p o r t
– A u g u s t
1 3 ,
2 0 0 8

Turnover for Selected Job Classes - Follow-Up Report
Turnover for Selected Job Classes - Follow-Up Report

At the June 3, 2008 Government Efficiency GMAP forum, the Governor asked whether the salary increases granted effective 7/1/07 had an impact on resolving turnover problems. This report serves as a follow-up response to that question.
At the June 3, 2008 Government Efficiency GMAP forum, the Governor asked whether the
salary increases granted effective 7/1/07 had an impact on resolving turnover problems.
This report serves as a follow-up response to that question.

The Department of Personnel selected certain job classes to research this issue. One or more of the following criteria were applied to select which jobs to look at:
The Department of Personnel selected certain job classes to research this issue. One or
more of the following criteria were applied to select which jobs to look at:

cell.tabletext:

Plan & Align

Job class received salary increase on 7/1/07 to bring it within market rates
Job class received salary increase on 7/1/07 to bring it within market rates
The table shown on page 2 lists the job classes reviewed. The findings are displayed graphically and discussed in more detail in the subsequent pages of this report.
The table shown on page 2 lists the job classes reviewed. The findings are displayed
graphically and discussed in more detail in the subsequent pages of this report.
The turnover formula used in this analysis included resignations, dismissals, and miscellaneous separations. It did not include turnover due to retirement. Statewide, for all job classes, the average turnover rate (excluding retirements) was 4.7% in FY 08 (as of 5/23/08).

miscellaneous separations. It did not include turnover due to retirement. Statewide, for all m i s c e l l a n e o u s

Most of the job classes selected for this review experienced reduced average turnover in FY 08. In some cases it may be too soon to tell whether the 7/1/07 salary increase made a difference. Also, other economic and management factors can affect turnover and hiring challenges.
Most of the job classes selected for this review experienced reduced average turnover in
FY 08. In some cases it may be too soon to tell whether the 7/1/07 salary increase made a
difference. Also, other economic and management factors can affect turnover and hiring
challenges.
Vacancy rate data was not available. However, headcount numbers give some indication of ability to successfully hire for these jobs.
Vacancy rate data was not available. However, headcount numbers give some indication of
ability to successfully hire for these jobs.

page.title:
Correctional Officers (CO)
Correctional Officers (CO)
page.ref:
Source: Department of Personnel
Source: Department of Personnel
page.enlisting:
▪ Both the 2 and 3 levels received a 10% salary increase, along with $10/hour assignment pay when conducting tactics/firearms training. Additionally, a 5% geographic assignment pay was granted for positions at Monroe, the State Penitentiary, and Coyote Ridge facilities. Regardless, Correction and Custody Officers still remain 20% behind market rate. ▪ Both the 2 and 3 level are now below the 4.7% statewide turnover average. ▪ DOC reports that both the Monroe and Walla Walla institutions are fully staffed. Anecdotally, DOC believes that the salary increases in conjunction with new recruitment and retention strategies have been positive. However, it is still too early to assess the full impact. ▪ Both the 2 and 3 levels received a 10% salary increase, along with $10/hour assignment pay when conducting tactics/firearms training. ▪ Anecdotal feedback from the Attorney ▪ Legal Secretaries are employed by seven agencies, with the large majority located in the Attorney General’s Office. ▪ The Legal Secretary 1 level received a 5% salary increase, and the 2 level received a 7.5% salary increase effective 7/1/2007. Positions in Seattle also were granted a 10% premium for geographic assignment pay. Legal Secretaries remain 22.5% behind market rate. ▪ While turnover decreased substantially, both are still notably higher than the 4.7% statewide average. ▪ Anecdotal feedback from the Attorney

page.title:
Registered Nurses
Registered Nurses
page.ref:
Source: Department of Personnel
Source: Department of Personnel
page.enlisting:
▪ RN’s received a 17.5% salary increase ▪ DOC reports that recent recruitment ▪ Registered Nurses (RN’s) are employed by five agencies: DSHS, DOC, DVA, and the Schools for the Blind and Deaf. ▪ Turnover dropped marginally at both levels. While turnover for RN 2’s remains above the 4.7% statewide average, it is comparable to the 8.4% national average for nurses reported in a July 2007 Price Waterhouse Cooper report. ▪ Headcount for both levels rose somewhat in 2008, indicating that agencies were able to successfully fill positions. ▪ DOC also reports a reduction in the need for contract Nurses to address vacant shifts and emergency on-call needs. Data reflect that 20 contractors have been hired into staff positions, while only two employees have left to work for nursing contractor firms. ▪ RN’s received a 17.5% salary increase
